settings.heading: Frequently Asked Questions

settings.text: Ameda

settings.heading: What if I'm experiencing issues with my pump?
settings.text: If you experience an issue with your pump, it falls within the warranty time frame, and you are the original owner, please contact our ParentCare team for assistance. In the United States, our Ameda ParentCare™ staff can answer consumer questions about proper use of Ameda® products, replacement parts and more. Give us a call at 1-866-992-6332 / 1-866-99-AMEDA or drop us a line at ParentCare@ameda.com. We are available Monday through Friday 8:00 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Central Time.

settings.heading: What are Ameda's Shipping Terms?
settings.text:
Ameda ships to all U.S. States and Puerto Rico. We do not ship Internationally.

What shipping & delivery options do you offer?

Due to carrier service challenges across the country, Ameda cannot currently guarantee expedited shipping and delivery dates. Delivery dates are estimations only. Any delivery date estimations are provided exclusively by the shipping carrier and Ameda does not offer any guarantee or warranty as to accuracy.

Please note that all shipping windows are using business days. Business days are defined as Monday – Friday, 8:00am – 2:00pm central time. Orders are not processed, shipped or delivered on weekends or holidays. Some locations outside of the contiguous U.S. require additional transit time.

Shipping Methods

Expedited Shipping

$18.90 for all orders

Orders placed before 1 p.m. central time Monday thru Friday will ship same day.

Orders placed after 1:30 p.m. central time Monday thru Friday, and weekend and holiday orders will ship the next business day.

Orders arrive within 2 business days.

Overnight Shipping

$30.90 for all orders

Orders placed before 1 p.m. central time Monday thru Friday will ship same day.

Orders placed after 1:30 p.m. central time Monday thru Friday, and weekend and holiday orders will ship the next business day.

Orders arrive within 1 business days.

settings.heading: Can I return or exchange an item?
settings.text:
Ameda offers a no hassle return policy for unopened items. Unopened items must have the original safety seal, that is put on by the factory, intact and untampered with.

All returns and exchanges can only be done if purchased from us directly via our eCommerce website. In order to qualify A return request must be received within 7 days of receiving the item with valid proof of purchase. All items must be unopened.

Please email us at ParentCare@ameda.com to receive return instructions. Include your order ID number, item(s) you would like to return, and reason for return. Once the return is approved we will email you the Return form and address for returning your item(s). “Return” constitutes receipt of the product by our warehouse. If you choose to use an Ameda.com return label, the cost of return will be subtracted from your refund amount.

Items must be in the original, undamaged manufacturer’s packaging with all packaging materials, including instruction booklets, packing inserts, plastic bags, and the warranty cards. The manufacturer’s labeled packaging must be enclosed within a new shipping carton.

Once we receive your return in the proper condition, we will then provide a refund to your payment account usually within 2-4 weeks. Returns cannot be accepted without a return form. Shipping, handling fees, discontinued products and special-order items if applicable, are not refundable.

settings.heading: What payment methods are accepted?
settings.text: We accept American Express™, Discover™, MasterCard™ and Visa™.

settings.heading: Do you have a recycling program?
settings.text: Ameda does not currently offer a recycling program for used pumps. We suggest you contact your local waste management provider to determine if there are options in your area for recycling.

settings.heading: Who should I contact if I have a performance issue with my pump?
settings.text: We recommend that you call our ParentCare Department when you have a few minutes available at 866-992-6332 M-F 8:00am-4:30pm CT for warranty assistance. Due to the nature of our product, we need to conduct our product troubleshooting over the phone. Troubleshooting may include listening to your motor, so please have your pump and pump accessories readily available when calling. General questions can be emailed to parentcare@ameda.com.

settings.heading: What if I have another issue with my pump?
settings.text: Your Finesse breast pump carries a two-year product warranty and all other personal electric breast pumps from Ameda carry a one-year product warranty from the date of receipt and our ParentCare staff is here to assist you during your breast pumping journey. Please call our ParentCare Department at 866-992-6332 M-F 8:00 am-4:30pm CT when you have a few minutes to discuss any issues you are experiencing. We will provide troubleshooting support over the phone to determine if a product related issue exists. If we determine that our product is the root cause of the issue you are experiencing, we will assist you under the terms of the product warranty. If a product related issue is not found, our ParentCare Specialists can support you further by providing additional product education and guidance that may help enhance your overall lactation and pumping experience.
Products

settings.heading: Mya and Mya Joy look similar – what is the main difference between the two pumps?
settings.text: Mya and Mya Joy are both small, lightweight personal use pumps. They both provide hospital strength performance and are designed for moms pumping on a daily basis. Mya includes an internal lithium battery and uses it own unique pump kit and flange system. Mya Joy has a internal battery back-up option that requires 4 AA batteries. Mya Joy is also compatible with most components in the Ameda HygieniKit including containers, tubing and CustomFit flanges.

settings.heading: Are the Mya family of pumps covered by insurance? How can I find out if my insurance plan covers them?
settings.text: The Mya and Mya Joy are covered by most insurance plans. To find out your options contact your insurance plan directly. Ameda also has a convenient web page to learn more and search for a Durable Medical Equipment (DME) provider that covers Ameda pumps.

settings.heading: I received an Ameda HygieniKit™ in the hospital – can I use it with my Mya Joy Pump?
settings.text: The HygieniKit you received in the hospital is mostly compatible with your Mya Joy pumping kit. All CustomFit™ flanges, containers/lids and tubing from your Ameda hospital kit can be used with the Joy. The diaphragm and valve pieces in the Joy are slightly different from those used in your HygieniKit so we recommend that only use the diaphragm and valves that come with your Mya Joy pump (just toss out the old ones). Two new sets of valves and diaphragms come with each Mya Joy pump.

settings.heading: Mya Joy is so small – will it be powerful enough to use when I go back to work?
settings.text: Yes. The Mya Joy pump features hospital strength performance and is designed for daily use by moms. It also features two modes of pumping (stimulation and expression) and a large range of settings for mom's comfort. Plus - Joy is so small and quiet, mom can take it with her where -ever she needs to go!

settings.heading: Does Mya Joy have a battery option?
settings.text: Yes. The Mya Joy has an internal battery compartment that requires 4 AA batteries.

settings.heading: Where can I buy spare parts for my Mya Joy pump?
settings.text: Mya Joy parts are conveniently available on the Ameda.com website and through many online retail and DME partners nationwide including Amazon.

settings.heading: Does Mya Joy have a battery option?
settings.text: Yes. The Mya has a built-in lithium battery that provides up to two hours of pumping time on a single charge. Mom can conveniently pump without having to worry about being plugged in!

settings.heading: I received an Ameda HygieniKit™ in the hospital – can I use it with my Mya Pump?
settings.text: The Mya pump uses a unique pump kit and flange system. The HygieniKit™ parts and CustomFit™ Flanges are not compatible with the Mya.
Pumping

settings.heading: How long should I pump?
settings.text:
An average pumping session is 10-15 minutes. Discontinue pumping after 15-20 minutes if no results are achieved.

  1. Attempt another pumping session in an hour or so after the baby feeds.
  2. Relax and allow your body to adjust to the feel of the pump. Your body recognizes the difference between the pump and your baby. Your body will adjust - this may take a few pumping sessions.

WATCH VIDEO

settings.heading: When should I pump?
settings.text:
Pumping is an art; the body needs me to adjust to this process. Practice and patience is required. We suggest you “get to know” your breast pump prior to returning to work or when first pumping to gather milk for a planned occasional separation. Pumping routinely to replace your nursing baby (i.e. returning to work):

You must use your breast pump in accordance with the nursing schedule established by the nursing baby.

Skipping pumping sessions will have a negative effect on your milk supply.

Pumping to gather milk for an occasional separation:

Use your breast pump in between baby's nursing sessions.

Single pump after a nursing session on the side that the baby finished nursing.

You may need to combine expressed milk from multiple pumping sessions to create a full feeding for baby

Pumping for a pre-mature or ill baby:

Consult your personal LC or other healthcare professional for further assessment of personal circumstances

Replacing Valves

WATCH VIDEO

settings.heading: How should I use/set my breast pump speed and suction dials?
settings.text:
Suction

  1. The suction dial should be set to your highest COMFORTABLE suction level.
  2. If any discomfort is felt, turn the suction down.

Speed

  1. Your pumping sessions should begin with the speed dial set at the highest speed level.
    1. This will encourage your body to release your milk (let down) so milk flow will start.
    2. This action mimics the suckling action of your baby at the beginning of a nursing session.
  2. Once milk flow has begun, slowly adjust the speed dial down, about half way
    1. This slower speed will effectively drain your breast of milk.
    2. This action mimics the longer and slower sucks of your baby during a nursing session, once milk is present and feeding starts.
  3. After milk flow slows, try to initiate another let down by turning the speed all the way up and repeating the process.
  4. Multiple let-downs occur during a nursing session with baby. For optimal milk output, it is important to mimic this pattern when using your breast pump.

WATCH VIDEO

settings.heading: How do I switch between single and double pumping?
settings.text: WATCH VIDEO
Troubleshooting

settings.heading: Troubleshooting Low Suction
settings.text:
Your breast pump valve should be replaced every 2 to 3 months depending on frequency of pumping. Low suction and other suction related issues are most often caused by damaged or worn valves, that need to be replaced. (Valves are the small, clear silicone, triangle shaped pieces that attach to the flange and hang down into the milk collection container during pumping). Valves are the “heart “of pump suction and therefore it is essential that these pieces are well-maintained during your pumping journey. To restore suction:

  1. Replace your current valves with brand new, unused valves.
  2. Check your flange fit:

Replacing Valves

https://youtu.be/nrCcw5eGYVQ

Flange Fit

https://youtu.be/34Ap1AjyWe8

settings.heading: Troubleshooting Uneven Suction or Suction on one side only
settings.text:
Uneven suction or suction on one side only may be a sign that it is time for routine replacement of your valves as the pump motor cannot create uneven suction or suction on one side only (unless you are set up to single pump). Valves are the small, clear silicone, triangle shaped pieces that attach to the flange and hang down into the milk collection container during pumping.)

  1. Replace the valve on the pumping side that is not working with a brand new, unused valve.

Using the wrong size the flange can create suction issues, discomfort while pumping and negatively affect your milk production.Learn more about how the proper flange fit can affect suction below:

  • Nipple size variance from breast to breast is not uncommon. You may need a different size flange for each breast
  • Using the wrong size flange can create suction issues, discomfort while pumping and negatively affect your milk production
  • Nipple size and breast tissue may naturally change during your breast pumping journey. The flange size that was proper for you when you began pumping may not be the proper size after time has passed
  • Verify that the tubing adapter is inserted firmly into the tubing adapter port
  • Visibly inspect the tubing adapter for any signs of damage
  • Defects in the tubing adapter may be the cause uneven suction
  • Focus on the side that isn’t working
  • Starting with the valve, switch piece parts, one at a time, from the side that is working to the side that isn’t working. This will isolate the piece part that is causing the issue.
  • If the lower suction stays with the same breast regardless of switching piece parts, then the suction issue is most likely due to Mom’s anatomy
  • Check flange fit on the nipple of the breast that is having low suction

Keep in mind that if only one side is working, you can single pump with the working side until you obtain replacement valves. To single pump:

  • Remove the tubing set up that is not providing suction from the pump.
  • Close off the port that you are not using with the white, tail like piece that is attached to the tubing adapter
  • You must close off the unused port to single pump.
  • Suction levels will be stronger when single pumping

Download the HygieniKit IFU for more information.

Uneven Suction

https://youtu.be/nrCcw5eGYVQ

settings.heading: Troubleshooting No Suction
settings.text:
1. Ensure that a valve is attached to each flange
  2. Ensure that the tubing adapter is firmly inserted into the adapter port
  3. Ensure diaphragms are placed in to the top of each flange
  4. If using battery power exclusively, switch to your power cord adapter

Flange Fit

Proper flange fit is essential to successful breast pumping. Pumping should not cause discomfort. Additionally, using the proper size flange will ensure maximum milk output. A good fit allows your nipple to move freely in the breast flange tunnel. You should see some space around the nipple. Only a little areola should be drawn into the tunnel with the nipple. The flange is too small if some or all of your nipple rubs against the sides of the breast flange tunnel. The flange is too big if more areola is drawn into the breast flange with your nipple and/or if your areola rubs against the side of the breast flange tunnel. Refer to your instruction manual for pictures of a good flange fit. You may also call our ParentCare Department at 866-992-6332 to conduct a flange fit over the phone. Click here to see our range of flanges.

Other Troubleshooting

https://youtu.be/DmwQztz9LFg

settings.heading: Troubleshooting Power Issues
settings.text:
If Your Pump is not powering on with the AC Adapter, please follow the below instructions for troubleshooting:

  1. If you have batteries installed in the battery compartment, remove the batteries
  2. Try using the pump in a different electrical socket.
  3. Ensure the AC Adapter is inserted into the AC Adapter port and not the Tubing Adapter port
  4. Try powering on the pump with 6 brand new premium AA batteries

If Your Pump is not working on battery power:

  1. Ensure the AC Adapter has been unplugged from the motor unit
  2. Ensure 6 brand new premium AA batteries have been installed

https://youtu.be/CoEeiPEUcfM
Insurance

settings.heading: What is the process for ordering a breast pump that is covered by insurance?
settings.text: Most health insurance plans cover the cost of a double electric breast pump. We recommend that you contact your insurance plan to ask about your benefits for a breast pump and what they require. Some insurance plans ask that you have a prescription from a doctor. Most will have you order your breast pump through a durable medical equipment provider (DME) on their list. To learn more about how this process works, check out our guide on receiving a free breast pump through insurance on

settings.heading: Will I need a prescription to order my breast pump through insurance?
settings.text: Each plan is different. We recommend calling your insurance plan to learn more. If a prescription is needed, contact your doctor to obtain a prescription in advance of placing the order for your breast pump. In some cases, your doctor may send the prescription directly to a specific DME. If this is the case, we recommend that follow up directly with this DME to see if additional information is needed to process your order.

settings.heading: Can I upgrade my breast pump to a different model?
settings.text: All health insurance plans are different. As a first step, ask your insurance plan. The second step is to see if the DME will allow you to upgrade your breast pump with an additional out of pocket fee. Many DMEs offer a range of upgrade options, as well as additional accessories available for purchase.

settings.heading: Is it possible to use funds from a Flexible Spending Account, Health Savings Account or Health Reimbursement Account to pay breast pump or breast pump accessories or breastfeeding supplies?
settings.text: This is often the case. Check with your employer or plan administrator to verify your benefits.
